research_goal:
To identify the visual, auditory, and interaction features of immersive 360° virtual reality (VR) experiences that most effectively elicit cognitive and neural responses differentiating individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or early Alzheimer’s disease from cognitively healthy older adults, and to determine which multimodal behavioral and physiological features—including eye gaze, head movement, and prefrontal hemodynamic activity (fNIRS)—best capture those differences.
The project will (1) design and iteratively test 360° video and spatial audio environments that vary in cognitive demand (e.g., attention, navigation, memory recall, emotional salience, and sensory complexity), and (2) analyze behavioral and neural data collected during these tasks to identify feature patterns that reliably distinguish cognitive status.
Participants aged 60–80 from outpatient memory clinics and matched healthy controls will complete the VR tasks while gaze, field-of-view dynamics, and fNIRS signals are recorded. Data-driven statistical and computational analyses will be used to identify the stimulus and response features most sensitive and specific to early cognitive decline, with diagnostic accuracy evaluated against established cognitive assessments (e.g., MoCA, CDR).
Primary objective: Define the key VR content and sensory features that elicit measurable cognitive signatures and establish a set of multimodal digital biomarkers (behavioral + neural) for early detection of Alzheimer’s-related impairment.

articles_with_reasoning.title: Immersive 360° VR Features and Multimodal Biomarkers for Early Alzheimer’s Detection
key_findings: High-realism 360° VR with spatial (ambisonic) audio and interactive tasks elicits measurable cognitive and emotional responses that differentiate MCI/early AD from healthy older adults.
Spatial navigation tasks—especially path integration and wayfinding with manipulated landmarks and distractors—are among the most sensitive VR paradigms for early Alzheimer’s-related impairment.
Multimodal behavioral and physiological features (eye gaze, head movement kinematics, and prefrontal fNIRS hemodynamics) show promise as digital biomarkers that classify cognitive status.

Eye-tracking metrics such as fixation duration on landmarks vs. distractors, scanpath length, gaze entropy, saccade dynamics, and field-of-view transitions distinguish MCI/early AD from controls during navigation and memory tasks.

Head movement features (yaw/pitch/roll dynamics, rotation rate, exploration coverage, movement variability, and gaze–head coupling) capture compensatory strategies and reduced exploratory behavior in impaired groups.
Prefrontal fNIRS (dlPFC/PFC) task-evoked changes in HbO/HbR during attention, dual-tasking, and executive-control demands index cognitive load and differ between MCI/early AD and controls.
Combining gaze, head motion, and fNIRS features with machine learning yields diagnostic accuracy comparable to standard assessments (e.g., MoCA, CDR), with navigation-focused tasks performing best.
Visual design features that heighten cognitive demand—rich landmark density, controlled visual clutter, dynamic scene changes, and perspective shifts—amplify group differences.
Spatial audio cues (directional landmarks, environmental soundscapes, and cue congruence/incongruence) enhance presence, support navigation memory, and increase sensitivity to impairment.
Interactive task elements—active locomotion, object interaction, mission-based goals, and time-pressured or dual-task conditions—boost ecological validity and reveal executive deficits.
Emotional salience and reminiscence content (e.g., nature scenes, autobiographical cues) improve engagement and mood and can modulate attention and memory performance in dementia populations.
VR-based cognitive training can improve visual recognition memory and relate to increased activity in task-relevant brain regions, suggesting trainability and neuroplasticity.
Older adults (60–80) from memory clinics can feasibly complete HMD-based 360° VR tasks, though comfort, motion sickness, and usability require careful design and onboarding.
Integration and synchronization of multimodal data streams (eye tracking, head kinematics, fNIRS) are feasible but technically demanding; standardized pipelines improve reliability.
articles_with_reasoning.relevance_to_goal: Findings specify which VR content and sensory features (high-realism 360° visuals, spatial audio cues, interactive navigation and memory tasks, emotional salience, and controlled sensory complexity) most strongly elicit differentiating cognitive signatures. They identify multimodal digital biomarkers—gaze behavior, head movement dynamics, and prefrontal fNIRS responses—that, when analyzed with machine learning, reliably distinguish MCI/early AD from healthy controls and complement standard assessments. This directly informs stimulus design, sensor selection, and feature engineering for the project’s diagnostic aims.
articles_with_reasoning.methodology_notes: This summary aggregates insights from recent web-accessible sources discovered via Perplexity, synthesizing reported methods, results, and implications across VR dementia research without conducting a systematic review or meta-analysis.
articles_with_reasoning.limitations: Web search aggregation may include non–peer-reviewed content (press releases, preprints), incomplete methodological details, and small-sample pilot studies, risking bias and overinterpretation. Evidence quality and generalizability vary, study protocols may differ substantially, and effect sizes or diagnostic metrics may be inconsistently reported. Conclusions should be validated against peer-reviewed literature, preregistered protocols, and larger, demographically diverse cohorts.

articles_with_reasoning.title: An exploration of distinguishing subjective cognitive decline and mild cognitive impairment based on resting-state prefrontal functional connectivity assessed by functional near-infrared spectroscopy
key_findings: Resting-state prefrontal functional connectivity measured with fNIRS shows group-level differences that help distinguish subjective cognitive decline (SCD) from mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
Individuals with MCI exhibit disrupted prefrontal connectivity organization relative to SCD, consistent with reduced network efficiency/strength within prefrontal circuits.
Connectivity-based features derived from resting-state fNIRS provide discriminatory power for classifying cognitive status along the SCD–MCI continuum.
Prefrontal connectivity alterations are associated with cognitive performance measures, supporting their potential as noninvasive biomarkers of early cognitive impairment.
articles_with_reasoning.relevance_to_goal: Identifies prefrontal fNIRS connectivity features that differentiate early-stage cognitive impairment (SCD vs MCI). These features can be targeted and modulated within immersive 360° VR tasks (e.g., attention, working memory, navigation) to elicit informative hemodynamic signatures. The findings support using prefrontal fNIRS metrics—complemented by behavioral measures like gaze and head movement—as multimodal biomarkers for early Alzheimer’s-related impairment.
articles_with_reasoning.methodology_notes: Cross-sectional comparison of SCD and MCI groups using resting-state fNIRS focused on the prefrontal cortex. Functional connectivity was computed from spontaneous hemodynamic fluctuations (e.g., HbO/HbR) across prefrontal channels, with network-level indices (e.g., connectivity strength/efficiency) used to assess group differences and classification utility.
articles_with_reasoning.limitations: Resting-state design (no task manipulation) limits inference about cognitive process-specific responses; prefrontal-only fNIRS montage may miss broader network changes; potential confounds from systemic physiological noise and motion; likely modest sample size and single-site recruitment may constrain generalizability and classification robustness.

articles_with_reasoning.title: Developing a novel brain‐based biomarker of mild cognitive impairment using time‐domain functional near‐infrared spectroscopy
key_findings: Time-domain fNIRS (TD-fNIRS) can capture depth-resolved cortical hemodynamic responses that differentiate individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) from cognitively unimpaired older adults.
Task-evoked prefrontal hemodynamics showed group differences consistent with altered executive/working-memory processing in MCI.
Combining TD-fNIRS-derived features with statistical/machine-learning models yields promising discriminatory power for an objective, brain-based MCI biomarker.
Depth sensitivity in TD-fNIRS helps mitigate superficial (scalp) confounds relative to conventional continuous-wave fNIRS, improving biomarker specificity to cortical activity.
articles_with_reasoning.relevance_to_goal: Directly aligns with the goal of identifying neural features (prefrontal hemodynamic activity) that distinguish early cognitive impairment. Demonstrates that TD-fNIRS can provide robust, depth-sensitive cortical signals suitable for integration with immersive 360° VR tasks, informing which fNIRS features (e.g., task-evoked HbO/HbR dynamics, depth-resolved measures) may best capture differences between MCI and healthy controls alongside behavioral measures like eye gaze and head movement.
articles_with_reasoning.methodology_notes: Utilized time-domain fNIRS to measure photon time-of-flight and derive depth-resolved hemoglobin concentration changes, improving separation of cortical from superficial signals. Participants (older adults with MCI and controls) completed cognitively demanding tasks targeting prefrontal function (e.g., executive control/working memory). Hemodynamic features were extracted from task-evoked responses and analyzed with statistical and machine-learning methods to build and evaluate an MCI biomarker.
articles_with_reasoning.limitations: Likely limited by sample size and single-center cohort, cross-sectional design without longitudinal validation, potential heterogeneity within MCI diagnoses, and focus on prefrontal regions that may not capture broader network dysfunction. TD-fNIRS, while more depth-sensitive, still faces challenges from motion and systemic physiology; external validation and assessment in more naturalistic/immersive settings (e.g., VR) are needed.

articles_with_reasoning.title: Developing a novel brain‐based biomarker of mild cognitive impairment using time‐domain functional near‐infrared spectroscopy
key_findings: Time-domain fNIRS (TD-fNIRS) signals from prefrontal cortex differentiated individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) from cognitively normal older adults during task-evoked conditions.
Hemodynamic features beyond simple amplitude (e.g., time-to-peak, rise/decay slopes, and HbO/HbR dynamics) contributed to discrimination, suggesting richer temporal features improve sensitivity.
Machine-learning models trained on TD-fNIRS-derived features showed promising classification performance for identifying MCI versus controls.
TD-fNIRS measures showed relationships with standard cognitive assessments, supporting clinical relevance.
TD-fNIRS’s depth-sensitive measurements provide advantages over continuous-wave fNIRS for brain-based biomarker development.
articles_with_reasoning.relevance_to_goal: Highly relevant: it identifies prefrontal hemodynamic features measurable with fNIRS that distinguish MCI from healthy aging. These features (HbO/HbR amplitude, latency, slope, and complexity) can be embedded as neural biomarkers within the proposed immersive 360° VR tasks and combined with behavioral metrics (eye/head movement) to improve early detection.
articles_with_reasoning.methodology_notes: Cross-sectional study comparing MCI and cognitively healthy older adults using time-domain fNIRS focused on prefrontal cortex during cognitive tasks. Extracted task-evoked hemodynamic features (e.g., HbO/HbR amplitudes, temporal dynamics), and applied machine-learning classification with internal validation. TD-fNIRS leveraged photon time-of-flight information to improve depth sensitivity and quantification compared to continuous-wave systems; performance was benchmarked against standard cognitive assessments.
articles_with_reasoning.limitations: Likely limited sample size and single-site data with cross-sectional design; preliminary/abstract-level reporting with limited methodological detail and absence of external validation; cortical coverage focused mainly on prefrontal regions; potential confounds from systemic physiology and motion; tasks were laboratory-based rather than ecologically rich (e.g., immersive VR), so generalizability to real-world or 360° environments remains to be established.

articles_with_reasoning.title: The effect of sensory manipulation on the static balance control and prefrontal cortex activation in older adults with mild cognitive impairment: a functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) study
key_findings: Sensory complexity during standing balance (foam surface and/or eyes closed) amplified differences between MCI and healthy controls in postural stability, with significant Group×Surface interactions for COP metrics (e.g., MVELO, MVELO_ml, 95%AREA-CE under eyes open; RMS, RMS_ml, 95%AREA-CE under eyes closed).
fNIRS revealed group differences in prefrontal activation: under eyes open, L-VLPFC, L-DLPFC, and R-DLPFC showed significant group effects; L-OFC showed a significant Group×Surface interaction.
Under eyes closed, group effects were observed in R-VLPFC, L-FPC, L-DLPFC, R-DLPFC, and R-OFC, indicating broader prefrontal involvement when visual cues are removed.
Findings support that older adults with MCI rely differently on prefrontal executive-control regions for balance under degraded or conflicting sensory conditions.
Combining balance metrics (COP) with prefrontal hemodynamics can distinguish MCI from cognitively healthy older adults, particularly when sensory inputs are manipulated.
articles_with_reasoning.relevance_to_goal: Directly relevant to selecting VR task features that elicit differential cognitive-neural responses in MCI: removing or degrading visual/proprioceptive cues and increasing sensory complexity increase group separability in both behavior (postural sway) and prefrontal hemodynamics. Although not in VR, the results suggest 360° VR scenarios that manipulate visual reliability, add sensory conflict, or simulate unstable surfaces may maximize discriminative fNIRS signatures (DLPFC/VLPFC/OFC/FPC) and movement-based biomarkers, informing multimodal feature design (e.g., head sway, gaze-field interactions, PFC Hb responses).
articles_with_reasoning.methodology_notes: Cross-sectional comparison of 21 older adults with MCI and 19 healthy controls performing four standing conditions: solid vs foam surface, eyes open vs eyes closed. Postural control measured via force platform (COP metrics including mean velocity, RMS, medial-lateral components, and 95% confidence ellipse area). Prefrontal hemodynamics recorded with fNIRS over ROIs (e.g., DLPFC, VLPFC, OFC, FPC). Statistical analyses tested Group, Surface, and Group×Surface effects separately for eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions, identifying condition-dependent behavioral and neural differences.
articles_with_reasoning.limitations: Not conducted in immersive VR; tasks limited to static standing balance, which may not generalize to complex cognitive demands (navigation, memory, emotion). Modest sample size and single-site cross-sectional design limit generalizability and causal inference. fNIRS coverage restricted to prefrontal cortex (no parietal/vestibular areas); signals can be affected by motion, scalp-hemodynamics, and hair. Potential confounding from sensory or motor differences not fully detailed (e.g., vision, vestibular function, medications).

articles_with_reasoning.title: Quantification of identifying cognitive impairment using olfactory-stimulated functional near-infrared spectroscopy with machine learning: a post hoc analysis of a diagnostic trial and validation of an external additional trial
key_findings: Task-evoked fNIRS responses in the orbitofrontal cortex during olfactory stimulation can discriminate MCI and Alzheimer’s disease from cognitively impaired suspects with high accuracy.
Machine learning on fNIRS oxygenation differences achieved 92.5% internal-validation accuracy and 82.5% external-validation accuracy for classifying MCI/AD.
For MCI specifically, machine learning outperformed traditional statistical models (internal: 86.0% vs 85.2%; external: 85.4% vs 68.8%).
Results indicate better generalization and reproducibility of ML-based models than classic statistical approaches across independent cohorts.
articles_with_reasoning.relevance_to_goal: Demonstrates that task-evoked prefrontal hemodynamic activity measured by fNIRS can serve as a digital biomarker to differentiate early cognitive impairment, supporting the project’s plan to collect fNIRS during cognitively engaging VR tasks. Although the stimulus here is olfactory rather than VR, the study validates the approach of using targeted, sensory/cognitive challenges to elicit discriminative fNIRS signatures and highlights orbitofrontal/prefrontal responsiveness as informative for ML-based classification.
articles_with_reasoning.methodology_notes: Two independent, patient-level, single-group diagnostic interventional trials (n=97 original; n=36 external) of older adults (>60) with suspected cognitive decline. Open-label olfactory stimulation while measuring orbitofrontal cortex oxygenation differences via fNIRS; additional assessments included medical interview, amyloid PET, brain MRI, MMSE, and a neuropsychological battery. Post hoc analysis compared classic statistical models to machine learning classifiers for diagnosing MCI and AD with internal and external validation.
articles_with_reasoning.limitations: External validation accuracy decreased vs internal, indicating potential cohort-specific effects. Small sample sizes, especially in the external trial. Single-group design with participants already suspected of impairment limits comparison to healthy controls. Open-label stimulation and post hoc analysis may introduce bias. fNIRS measurements were limited to orbitofrontal cortex and to olfactory tasks, which may constrain generalizability to other cognitive domains or sensory modalities.
